entry.title: Building a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views ‚Äì Part 3: Description for Hierarchy
entry.content:
Table of Contents:

  • Overview on this Blog
  • Approach
  • Technical Details & Source Code
  • Handling SACAccountType for hierarchy nodes
  • Loading hierarchy node descriptions in SAC
  • Conclusion

Overview on this Blog

Hi SAP Community,
This is part three of a three part blog series on How to Build a GL Account Hierarchy for SAC Planning with CDS Views.

  • Part1 - Loading the ID & DESC of the GL
  • Part2 - Loading the hierarchy
  • Part3 - Loading the Desc for the Hierarchy nodes üëà

In Part 1, we focused on loading the GL Account ID and Description into an SAC public dimension by selectively filtering GLs from the Financial Statement Version (FSV).
In Part 2, we built the GL hierarchy structure, covering both leaf-level GLs and header nodes using CDS views.

In this final part, we will complete the hierarchy setup by loading the descriptions for hierarchy header nodes, so that the hierarchy in SAC is not only functional but also readable and user-friendly. Without descriptions , the Header nodes appear with technical IDs and the hierarchy becomes difficult to understand for business user. 

 

Approach

The idea here is simple, the hierarchy structure is already available in ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC. The hierarchy node texts are stored in HRRP_NODET. We join both using the hierarchy node ID. This approach ensures the texts are dynamically picked up from the source system and any changes to node descriptions are reflected automatically in SAC.

 

Technical Details & Source Code

@AbapCatalog.sqlViewName: 'ZSQL_HIERTXT'
@AbapCatalog.compiler.compareFilter: true
@AbapCatalog.preserveKey: true
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'Text for Hierarchy nodes'
@Analytics.dataExtraction.enabled: true
@OData.publish: true
define view ZCDS_GLHIER_TXT as select distinct from 
ZCDS_GLHIER_FLAT_SAC as a left join hrrp_nodet as b on
a.Parent = b.hrynode {
    key a.Parent,
    b.nodetxt,
    a.MasterParent,
    case when a.Parent='0FSV1' then '' else a.SACAccountType end as SACAccountType
}
where b.hryid='FSV1' and b.spras='E' -- Choose your FSV and Language key as English

Handling SACAccountType for hierarchy nodes

In many systems, SACAccountType is not maintained at hierarchy node level. In such cases, we can derive or retain the account type based on the master hierarchy branch. This is important because:

  • SAC relies on SACAccountType to understand sign behavior.
  • Expense and Liability nodes need to subtract during aggregation.
  • Income and Asset nodes need to add.

By passing or deriving the account type consistently, we ensure correct aggregation behavior across all hierarchy levels.

P.S: In scenarios where hierarchy nodes involve multiple account types, inverse formulas can be provided to help SAC handle aggregation events correctly.

Loading hierarchy node descriptions in SAC

Hierarchy texts are loaded as a separate query in the SAC public dimension using our ZCDS_GLHIER_TXT CDS view. Only hierarchy node descriptions are updated whereas the existing hierarchy structure remains unchanged. Once this step is completed both GL accounts and hierarchy nodes display meaningful texts. The GL Account Public dimension will be fully ready and can be used in the planning model. This when consumed in the Input sheets becomes easier to understand for users.

The sample result would be like this. 

ID

Description

Hierarchy

Account type

40010000

Revenue - Good (Export)

FSV1_019

INC

40010001

Revenue - Good (Service)

FSV1_019

INC

FSV1_08

Turnover

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_09

Cost of Sales

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_011

Other Income

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_017

Taxation

FSV1_0FSV1

INC

FSV1_018

Local Sales

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_019

Export Sales

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_020

Lease Income

FSV1_08

INC

FSV1_0FSV1

Financial statement

FSV1_

 

FSV1_

 

<root>

 

With this final step:

  1. GL Account IDs and descriptions are loaded
  2. Hierarchy structure (leaf and header nodes) is built
  3. Hierarchy node descriptions are applied

This completes our end-to-end setup of a future-proof GL Account public dimension for SAC Planning using CDS views.

 

Conclusion

In this three-part series, we covered how to build a clean and scalable GL Account hierarchy for SAC Planning by selectively extracting FSV branches, constructing the hierarchy using CDS views, and finally enriching it with hierarchy node descriptions. This approach helps keep the SAC model & Input sheet clean, planning-friendly, and adaptable to future changes in the source system.

I hope this blog was helpful and proves useful for your upcoming planning implementations. If you found it helpful, feel free to hit a like, follow my profile, and drop a comment below. I‚Äôd love to hear your feedback.

entry.title: issue with duplicate Business Partner / Supplier / Customer creation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

We are facing an issue with duplicate Business Partner / Supplier / Customer creation in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud.

System Details

  • Solution: SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (2SL)

  • Apps Used:

    • Maintain Business Partner

    • Manage Supplier Master Data

    • Manage Customer Master Data

  • Country: India

Issue Description

While creating Business Partner / Supplier / Customer master data, the system is not checking for duplicate records, even when key attributes like GSTIN, Name, and Address are identical.

This results in:

  • Multiple suppliers/customers created with the same GSTIN

  • Manual duplicate cleanup and audit concerns

Expected Behavior

When creating a BP/Supplier/Customer:

  • System should detect duplicates based on GSTIN (Exact Match), Name, and Address.

  • Display warning or error depending on configuration

  • Prevent creation of suppliers/customers with same GSTIN

What We Have Checked

  • Using standard Fiori apps (not Migration Cockpit)

  • GSTIN is maintained in BP tax data

  • Duplicate check does not trigger during Save

  • No error or warning message is shown

Questions

  1. How do we configure GST-specific duplicate checks in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud?

  2. Which app or configuration controls duplicate detection for Business Partners?

  3. Is GSTIN-based duplicate prevention supported in Public Cloud?

  4. Are there any known limitations or SAP Notes related to this?

Regards,

Siva.

entry.title: Inbound Interface: EDI ‚Üí SAP BTP (Integration Suite with TPM) ‚Üí SAP S/4HANA (via IDoc) for B2B
entry.content:
This Blog will guide you to set up an inbound EDI-to-IDOC integration using SAP BTP‚Äôs Trading Partner Management (TPM). It involves creating company and partner profiles, defining identifiers, systems, and communications, then configuring agreements and mapping to route EDI messages through BTP IS to SAP S/4HANA via IDOC.

Step 0: Create MIG

0.1: Create a MIG in your Integration Advisor as per below details and use that MIG in the steps 3.2 and 4.3 and refresh & save it.

Step 1: Create Company Profile

Create a new Company for ‚ÄúCPI‚Äù.

Note: Only 1 Company Profile can exist per tenant.

1.1: Navigate to the Design tab, choose the B2B Scenario, then select Company Profile within TPM (Trading Partner Management), and click the Create profile button.

Provide Company Name and short name then save it.

1.2: Create Identifier in above company which you have created, in the right side there is Identifier tab at top. You can have as many Identifiers for your Company as you want. In our case we have to create 2 Identifiers for our company, one is for SAP S4 and another for EDI.

Note: for EDI, check Custom Scheme as per EDI and provide Scheme code and Scheme Name as per requirement.

1.3: Go to the Systems Tab of created Company and Create a System.

Click on + button to create new Type.

1.4: Select/Click on above system which you have created, in that new option will open in right side as Create Type System.

Note: The Version of System should match the DOCREL in your EDI Control Record (EDI_DC40) from your IDOC, so please provide the same version which is available in IDOC.

1.5: Select Communication as per the below image and create it.

As we are going to map the EDI file to an IDOC and post it to SAP S4, we need to define a Receiver Communication for our Company. Provide all IDOC details and save it.

 

Step 2: Create Trading Partners

2.1: Go to your Trading Partner Management (B2B Scenarios) in Design and select Partner Profile Tab. Click on Create Trading Partner and provide all details.

2.2: Create Identifiers for above Trading Partner which we have created.

Note: Refer 1.2 for details.

2.3: Create a System for Trading Partner which you have created. Go to the Systems Tab of created Trading Partner and Create a System.

Note: Refer 1.3 for more details.

2.4: Select/Click on above system which you have created, in that new option will open in right side as Create Type System.

Create a Type System for the Trading Partner with the details.

Note: Refer 1.4 for details.

2.5: Create Communication for Trading Partner.

As we will receive the EDI File from our trading partner (HF) from SFTP, we will need to create a Sender Communication for this Trading Partner in TPM. 

Step 3: Define Agreement Template

3.1: We will create an Agreement Template in our Trading Partner Management. The Agreement Template here is where CUSTOMER1 is the Initiator and SAPS4Hana200 is the Reactor.

Select Agreement Templates in Trading Partner Management and click on create button.

3.2: Select MIG if you have created.

3.3: Define the Communication channel (IDoc) in your Template and save it.

Step 4: Define Agreement

4.1: Create an Agreement in your Trading Partner Management as per below details.

You will now see D.96B.S3 in your Trading Partner Agreement. Select that and the remaining Identifiers as per screenshot below.

4.2: Provide Sender Communication Details in Trading Partner Agreement. Select Sender Communication.

Select Communication and save it.

4.3: Provide Sender Interchange Details in Trading Partner Agreement.

Choose MIG and save it.

4.4: Provide Mapping Details in Trading Partner Agreement.

Note: As per our scope, we will not use MAG and use a Message Mapping in Cloud Integration. Select option ‚ÄúCustomized Mapping Processing‚Äù and provide your Process Direct endpoint of your Iflow (/tpm/Customer1/EDIFACT_ORDERSD86B/IDOC_ORDERS_ORDERS05). Note this endpoint as you will use it in the next step.

4.5: Activate your Trading Partner Agreement.

 

Conclusion:

By following these steps, you can successfully set up an inbound EDI-to-IDOC integration using SAP BTP‚Äôs Trading Partner Management (TPM). The process involves creating company and partner profiles, defining identifiers and systems, configuring communications, and establishing agreements. Leveraging MIG for message structure and customized mapping in Cloud Integration ensures that EDI messages are accurately transformed and routed to SAP S/4HANA via IDoc. This approach provides a standardized, scalable, and efficient way to manage B2B integrations on SAP BTP.

entry.title: Re: Indirect tax for plants abroad with a permanent establishement
entry.content: Indirect tax treatment for plants abroad with a permanent establishment (PE) generally requires the foreign plant to be treated as a separate taxable entity in that jurisdiction. This means VAT, excise, or other indirect taxes must be registered and reported locally, rather than consolidated under the parent company.

entry.title: How to retain cohort membership history when learners are relegated to a new cohort?

Scenario
We manage class cohorts and sometimes learners are relegated (moved to a different cohort due to performance or compliance).

Problem
When a learner is removed from their previous cohort and added to a new one, the old record disappears. We lose the history of cohort membership and the dates of when they were in the previous cohort.

entry.title: Re: Unexpected document Split Clearing Account
entry.content: Hi, The behavior you're observing is always happening and is working as designed. FI direct postings to WBS elements will consistently generate document split clearing account 29500100 due to dimensional balancing requirements, while CO activity allocations will not trigger this clearing account usage. This difference is fundamental to how S/4HANA handles FI versus CO postings and should be expected in all similar scenarios. If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better. Br.Bob

entry.title: How to apply a dynamic discount (Z-table) to interest items in ECC 6.0 without separate credit memos
entry.content:
Hi experts,

I am facing a major technical blocker in ECC 6.0 EHP8 (FI-CA 618 / IS-U active). We need to apply a dynamic discount from a Z-table (Doc Type + Installment count) to the final interest amount in FPR1.

What we have already exhausted:

1. Event 2085: Blocked by STAKZ (Taxes). Cannot use it when tax indicators are present.

2. Note 902456: Subroutine for v_zins only triggers with RFKN1-GZVER active, and even then, the OLD_INTEREST vs NEW_INTEREST comparison fails, causing a consistency error.

3. Events 0350 / 2095: Manual changes to T_FKKIA or FKKOP are either overwritten or rejected by the core calculation engine.

4. Implicit Enhancements: We have analyzed the call stack from ADD_INTEREST_AND_FEE down to FKK_INTEREST_CALC. We couldn't find a viable enhancement point that allows us to bypass the final validation without modifying the standard.

The Question: Since we cannot find an enhancement point or a standard event that works with taxes and passes the consistency check, how can we persist a discounted interest amount? Is there any "hidden" way to influence the calculation parameters so the ACxx rules "believe" the discounted amount is the correct one? Or is it technically impossible in ECC 6.18 to adjust the interest amount without a separate credit memo?

entry.title: Re: Stock & Quality Management by Handling Unit (Bags / P...
entry.content:
Good day @c_walid 

Thank you for your question

In summary, the answer to whether you can use Handling Unit as a business stock and inspection dimension e.g., for bags, pallets not only as a packaging object in public cloud will depend on whether you stay in Inventory Management only or if you are using Warehouse Management capabilities.

Let us look at what you can do in regard to:

Stock visibility by bags or pallets:

  • So, the answer to your question is, yes, you can list and analyse stock by Handling Unit when you make use of the standard HU monitoring apps, which enables you to see how many pallets exist as number of HUs. However, standard stock overview apps by default are still quantity based or alternative UoM and not counted by HU. See Handling Unit Management and Handling Units in Cloud Processes for more details.

Physical inventory by pallet or by bag:

  • In inventory management only, physical inventory is fundamentally quantity based. Which means you can count in UoM. See Handling Units in Inventory Management and Manage Physical Inventory Documents for more insights.
  • If you were to use Warehouse Management, you can run warehouse processes where Hus are handled explicitly, including HU focused operational steps.

Handling Unit Quality inspection:

  • In public Cloud, quality execution for HU is mainly supported when you use Warehouse Management integration with QM rather than only inspecting lot per HU as the primary object. See Quality Management in Warehousing and Warehouse Internal Inspections for some details.
  • The classical Quality Inspection for Handling Units is clearly documented here for on premise.

 

My workaround recommendations are as follows:

  • For bag or pallet stock analysis: Make use of Monitor Handling Units for HU counts and Stock Single Material for quantity totals. See Monitor Handling Units for more details.
  • If you want inventory by bag or pallet without EWM, I suggest you use Alternative UoM (BAG, PAL) and count in that UoM.
  • If you want HU selective quality control, then use warehouse inspection and stock status flows to isolate and manage only your affected Hus
  • If your requirement is strict HU based inspection lots and UDs, you can validate whether you need Private Cloud or On Prem QM HU inspection scope.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Tricentis integration with Cloud ALM for Test automation
entry.content:
This integration combines the application lifecycle management capabilities of SAP Cloud ALM with the test automation capabilities of Tricentis, allowing you to design automated, functional, end-to-end software tests and manage them with test orchestration, execution monitoring, and reporting capabilities.

Let's start with SAP Cloud ALM tenant.

1. Add New Service in Cloud ALM

  • Log in to your Cloud ALM tenant
  • Navigate to: Administration ‚Üí Landscape Management ‚Üí Services & Systems ‚Üí Add ‚Üí New Service

Enter the following details:

  • Name: (Your preferred name)
  • System Number: (Any value)
  • Role: Test
  • Service Type: Tricentis
  • Deployment Model: SAP Public Cloud
  •  Root URL:  Add _sap-integration at the end of your tricentis URL.

Save your changes and proceed to the Endpoints section.

2. Configure Endpoints

  • Root URL: Same as above
  • Authentication Type: OAuth credentials

3. Retrieve OAuth Credentials

To find the Client ID and Client Secret:  

  •  Use  _identity/apiDocs/swagger/index.html as extension to your tricentis URL and login to Tricentis account.
  • Click on Authorize button and then click on Get.

  • Use GET /_identity/api/v1/applications to obtain the Application (Client) ID for Tricentis Cloud API

Click on Try it out and Execute 

Scroll down till Response Body and Search for 

"name": "Tricentis Cloud API"

Copy the Application ID.

  • For Client Secret: Use GET /_identity/api/v1/applications/{id}/secrets (replace {id} with your Application ID). Application ID can be fetched from Get: Applications.

Click on Try it out and add application ID fetched from previous step, Click on Execute.

In Response Body you will find Client ID and Client Secret. 

 

4. Token Secure URL

  • From your Tricentis home page, navigate to your profile and Click on edit profile in Okta

  • Copy the URL up to .com, then add /oauth2/default/v1/token to the end

  • Use this as the Token Secure URL and check the connection.

Once the connection is successfully established, you‚Äôll be able to import and execute Tricentis test cases directly within SAP Cloud ALM.

You can try this in SAP Cloud ALM Demo Tenant using Tricentis Cloud trail version. 

Conclusion: 

By successfully integrating SAP Cloud ALM with Tricentis, organizations can significantly streamline their end-to-end application lifecycle and testing processes. This combined solution empowers teams to design, orchestrate, and manage automated test cases directly within SAP Cloud ALM, leveraging Tricentis‚Äôs powerful test automation capabilities.

SAP Cloud ALM

entry.title: Re: Disable Create Action in Manage Supplier Master Data...
entry.content:
Good day @sandeep_shankarampet 

Thank you for your question

To summarise, yes, your observation on Adapt UI hiding the Create button globally is correct and is therefore not a role-based authorisation control. In public cloud, the supported way you can control Create is through authorisation. See Configuring Business Roles for more details.

In public cloud you can prevent creation for specific roles by removing Create Suppler authorisation from those roles. The button will typically be disabled, or the action will be rejected by the backend. See Maintain Business Roles for more insights.

The public cloud does not provide the option, from a clean core perspective, to use Adapt UI to remove the create button for only some roles. Reason is, it impacts all users of that adaptation layer. See Adapting the UI for more information.

All three roles you mentioned likely include one or more business catalogs that grant Supplier Create authorisation for the app, which is likely the root cause. In public cloud you do not maintain authorisation objects directly rather you control it through catalog assignment and release restriction.

 

In your tenant, you need to identify which catalog grants Create for this app.

  • Go to IAM Information System, search for Manage Supplier Master Data (F1053A). Use the IAM details to determine which business catalogs are required for the app and which authorisations are linked to create vs change.

  • Next you need to split the business roles by capability (between Create and Non create). For the two roles that must not create; open Maintain Business Roles, then open Role A (no create) √† Assigned Business Catalogs, remove the catalog identified in Step 1 that provide create supplier capability. Keep only catalogs that provide display if you require.

  • Repeat the same process for Role B
  • For the one role that you want to have the create functionality, open Role C and ensure it contains catalogs that provide the create capability.
  • Finally, you should validate your changes by login in with users A, B and C to confirm your modifications.

Note that the restriction fields you see in Maintain Business Roles are mainly for data visibility and organisational filtering, not for you to hide UI actions like Create. You can control actions through delivered catalogs. See Data Visibility Based on Restrictions and Maintain Business Roles for more information.

If you require the button to be removed and not just disabled, as a workaround, you can provide a separate tile or app approach for those roles while you keep the F1053A for creators or accept disable Create for non creator roles.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris
